author: By Matt Richtel and David Williams
title: The Refries That Bind: A Cavernous Cantina Returns, Cliff Divers and All
description: With “infinity dollars” poured in by the creators of “South Park,” a fabled Colorado restaurant reopens with the same 1970s vibe and drastically improved food.
content: Colorado’s defining features include glorious mountain peaks, vivid seasonal colors, skiing and a widespread compulsion to exercise and eat well. But for generations of Colorado children, arguably the most commonly shared experience involved Casa Bonita, a vast, filthy, poorly-lit, underground restaurant with food that many diners deemed barely edible.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jennifer Pahlka
description: The June 6, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jennifer Pahlka. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Watched Him Kiss Someone New’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: I called him “Cup Guy” because in every photo on his dating profile, he held a cup. Last Pride month, our relationship fizzled. Five months later, I watched him kiss someone new at “our” bar in the West Village. During the kiss, Cup Guy’s eyes were locked on mine. I couldn’t look away. Later, I saw him order two vodka-Cokes, likely for himself and his date. Surprise: He sauntered to my table. “Take it,” he said, grinning, sliding a drink over, before leaving abruptly. I stared at this cup, wondering if it was a peace offering or an invitation. — Dillon Fernando
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: From Tel Aviv to Riyadh
description: My recent journey through the Middle East was unlike anything I’ve ever experienced in a region that has long been my second home.
content: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — “Your final destination is Tel Aviv?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Art of Reusing Plastic
description: The artists Beverly Barkat and Germane Barnes play with discarded plastic — including bottles, cups and printer cartridges — to explore the possibilities of reinventing waste.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll meet two artists who observed World Environment Day with creations made from discarded plastics. We’ll also find out why a court-appointed official says the police anti-crime units are still stopping and frisking people illegally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: A First Try of Apple’s $3,500 Vision Pro Headset
description: I briefly got my hands on Apple’s new high-tech goggles, which impressed and creeped me out and raised a question: Why do we need these?
content: I got a sneak peek into Apple’s vision for the future of computing on Monday. For about half an hour, I wore the $3,500 Vision Pro, the company’s first high-tech goggles, which will be released next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Prince Harry Takes on Tabloids, but U.K. Media Already Forced to Turn the Page
description: The U.K. news landscape has shifted since the prince says he was hacked more than a decade ago, with hefty legal settlements, prison time for journalists and the threat of regulation forcing change.
content: In his hacking lawsuit being heard in a British court, Prince Harry aims to land another blow against a tabloid industry that has long been accused of widespread privacy abuses but that has been forced in recent years to rein in its excesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: Never Inevitable
description: “Like many women, I have been routinely harassed simply for looking the way I look, my boundaries violated both physically and sexually.”
content: When Ariella Steinhorn was 15, a group of teenage boys tackled her at a bus stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: ‘He Is Seriously Not Going to Be President.’ Our Columnists and Writers Discuss Mike Pence.
description: Everyone agrees: He has great hair.
content: As Republican candidates enter the race for their party’s 2024 presidential nomination, Times columnists, Opinion writers and others will assess their strengths and weaknesses with a scorecard. We rate the candidates on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the candidate will probably drop out before any caucus or primary voting; 10 means the candidate has a very strong chance of receiving the party’s nomination next summer. This entry assesses Mike Pence, the former vice president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Maggie Haberman
title: Chris Christie Announces ’24 Run, Taking Square Aim at Trump
description: At his New Hampshire kickoff, the former New Jersey governor called Donald Trump “a bitter, angry man” and said his time in office was a failure.
content: Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey who was eclipsed by Donald J. Trump in the 2016 presidential primaries, announced on Tuesday that he would seek the 2024 Republican nomination, setting up a rematch with the former president and expanding the field of G.O.P. candidates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: Scientists Discover a Virgin Birth in a Crocodile
description: The act of reptile reproduction suggests that dinosaurs and pterosaurs may have been capable of parthenogenesis, too, much like the creatures in “Jurassic Park.”
content: In January 2018, a female crocodile in a Costa Rican zoo laid a clutch of eggs. That was peculiar: She’d been living alone for 16 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: What Does it Take to Run a Museum? The Job Description Is Changing.
description: It’s not only about the art anymore: Today’s museum leaders must increasingly confront staff revolts and calls to return looted art while navigating labor unrest and social justice controversies.
content: Art world luminaries gathered in the rotunda of the Guggenheim last month to nibble cauliflower shawarma, sip Prosecco and bid farewell to Richard Armstrong, who this summer will conclude his 14-year tenure as the museum’s director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Prosecuting Florida’s Migrant Flights Would Face Legal Hurdles
description: Legal questions have been raised about migrant flights Florida chartered to Sacramento and Martha’s Vineyard. But state officials say they were voluntary, and proving otherwise could be tough.
content: When a private plane chartered by the government of Florida dropped off bewildered Latin American migrants recently on a pair of flights from Texas to California, Gov. Gavin Newsom described it as a possible “kidnapping” and called for an investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Judson Jones
title: Wildfire Smoke Blots Sun and Prompts Health Alerts in Much of U.S.
description: The smoke was pouring across the border from Canada, where hundreds of wildfires remain unchecked, and the hazardous smoke conditions are expected to linger through Wednesday and perhaps until later in the week.
content: An eye-watering and cough-inducing smoky haze from Canadian wildfires smothered a swath of the eastern and northern United States on Tuesday, with officials warning residents with health risks to stay indoors and keep their windows closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Chen
title: Before Networking Was Invented, She Had a Network
description: In Lisa See’s new novel, a doctor draws support from a variety of strong relationships — and from her own privilege.
content: “Whether animal or woman, we are a man’s possessions. We women exist to give him heirs and feed, clothe and amuse him. Never forget that,” Respectful Lady instructs our narrator at the beginning of Lisa See’s latest novel, “Lady Tan’s Circle of Women.” This scene, which takes place as mother and daughter endure the anguish of foot binding, sets the tone for the book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Riding
title: Françoise Gilot, Artist in the Shadow of Picasso, Is Dead at 101
description: An accomplished painter (and memoirist) in her own right, she was long his lover until she did what no other mistress of his had ever done: She walked out.
content: Françoise Gilot, an accomplished painter whose art was eclipsed by her long and stormy romantic relationship with a much older Pablo Picasso, and who alone among his many mistresses walked out on him, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Manhattan. She was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: How Christie and Trump’s Friendship Flourished, Then Deteriorated
description: The two men had a relationship that could be genuinely warm, and at other times transactional. Now they are vying for the presidency in open hostility.
content: Their friendship began after an introduction through Donald J. Trump’s sister. It ended nearly 20 years later, when Mr. Trump refused to concede the 2020 election to Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Atkins
title: From Lahore to Orford Ness, Searching for the Roots of Trauma
description: In “A Flat Place,” Noreen Masud is drawn to the plains of England and Scotland to find healing.
content: Flatlands can be places of unnerving paradox. There, you can’t be taken by surprise, but nor can you hide; any feeling of liberation tends to be constrained by a barb of danger; and while you may be granted a glimpse of the infinite, you’re also made to feel hyper-aware of your own body. For Noreen Masud, a lecturer in 20th-century literature at the University of Bristol, “it’s as though the landscape is sending us a message that we’re unable to decipher.” In “A Flat Place,” she travels to five landscapes in England and Scotland in an effort to interpret them: the Cambridgeshire fens, the shingle promontory of Orford Ness, the tidal flats of Morecambe Bay, the Town Moor in Newcastle and the islands of Orkney. She also seeks to interpret their appeal, for while this is a kind of quest narrative, that quest’s true objective might be to answer the question: What am I looking for? And though the journeys together have something of the quality of a pilgrimage to a healing spring, Masud is too skeptical to anticipate any sort of nature cure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Surico
title: Make Way for the Bike Bus
description: For the school commute, families are taking to the streets with two wheels. Some have termed the movement “kidical mass.”
content: On a recent Wednesday morning in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, parents and children met up in McCarren Park with all manner of wheels: electric cargo bikes, scooters, tricycles, classic cruisers. By 7:30 a.m., about 30 people were ready to roll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Storming a Trench Is Treacherous Business. Here’s How It’s Done.
description: Assaults on trenches can be stealthy, or deafeningly loud. Either way, they are nerve-racking. Here’s how one Ukrainian unit says it carried out a successful attack earlier this month.
content: Armies have been storming trench lines for more than a hundred years, but for all the advances in military technology, it is no less harrowing now than it was when soldiers were crossing the muddy battlefields of World War I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘All Man’ Review: International Male, a Wishbook on Many Levels
description: The catalog was more than a place to peruse the latest fashions. It reshaped society’s definitions of masculinity.
content: One of the most famous “Seinfeld” episodes involves Jerry wearing a flamboyant “puffy shirt” — which was pretty much a copy of the “ultimate poet’s shirt” sold by International Male. The piece of apparel might be a pop culture footnote now, but for a while the mail-order catalog that inspired it meant quite a lot, as evidenced by Bryan Darling and Jesse Finley Reed’s documentary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raksha Vasudevan
title: The Immigrant Experience in a Danish Butter Cookie Tin
description: Ubiquitous in immigrant households, the cookie tin might be a more apt metaphor for our journeys than the melting pot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: Put a Bird on It? Ancient Egypt Was Way Ahead of Us.
description: A 3,300-year-old palace mural offers an exquisitely detailed view of several bird species, and presents an artistic mystery.
content: A century ago, archaeologists excavated a 3,300-year-old Egyptian palace in Amarna, which was fleetingly the capital of Egypt during the reign of the pharaoh Akhenaten. Situated far from the crowded areas of Amarna, the North Palace offered a quiet retreat for the royal family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: A Brief History of Insults (and So’s Your Mother)
description: Since the beginning of time, humans have looked for ways to knock one another down a few pegs. We really haven’t changed much.
content: Many animal species have some sort of group hierarchy, where the leaders work very hard to remain at the top of the ladder and the rest of the group desperately clings to the rungs below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: The Full List of the 2023 James Beard Chef and Restaurant Award Winners
description: After facing questions about its new processes, the James Beard Foundation held its annual gala in Chicago on Monday.
content: The James Beard Foundation presented its coveted culinary awards for 2023 in Chicago on Monday night, with the top awards going to Rob Rubba of Oyster Oyster in Washington, D.C., as outstanding chef and to Friday Saturday Sunday in Philadelphia as outstanding restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: Being Gay Is Illegal in Many Countries. L.G.B.T.Q. Travelers Are Going Anyway.
description: Tropical reefs, safaris, the pyramids: L.G.B.T.Q. travel companies deliver dream vacations, even to places where being out and proud could land you in prison.
content: A romantic island getaway in the Maldives. A safari in Kenya. A visit to the pyramids in Egypt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Through Ties to Saudis, Golf Deal Promises Benefits to Trump
description: The new alliance between the PGA Tour and LIV Golf is the latest example of how the former president’s relationship with Saudi Arabia has yielded gains, and criticism, for both.
content: The surprising deal on Tuesday ending a civil war in the world of professional golf stands to produce benefits for former President Donald J. Trump’s family business by increasing the prospect of major tournaments continuing to be played at Trump-owned courses in the United States and perhaps abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Kwame Opam
title: Ukraine Dam Disaster: What We Know
description: A dam in southern Ukraine was split in half, but it is unclear who caused the damage. Thousands are being evacuated as dangerous volumes of water gush downstream.
content: A critical dam on the Dnipro River in southern Ukraine broke overnight on Tuesday, endangering thousands of people who live downstream. It was not immediately clear who caused the breach. Ukraine blamed Russia, saying there had been an explosion in an engine room. Russia said the Ukrainian forces had carried out a sabotage attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: Foul Witch Summons the Ghost of Blanca
description: A new restaurant in the East Village brings some tasting-menu sophistication to an à la carte dining room.
content: Whenever I eat in a tasting-menu restaurant — which is several times a month and would be several times a week if I reviewed each one that came along — I find myself wondering what I’d think of the same food if a normal restaurant served it. If I ordered à la carte, would everything taste as good? Would my check be lower? Would I still walk out feeling as if I’d swallowed a couch cushion?
source.name: The New York Times

title: 7 New Songs You Should Hear Now
description: Listen to Jorja Smith, Silvana Estrada, Miya Folick and more recent highlights.
content: There’s “weekly,” “biweekly,” even “triweekly” — but is there a word for something that happens once every four weeks?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Americans Were Aware of Intelligence Warning of Ukrainian Pipeline Attacks
description: The Washington Post reported on Tuesday that U.S. intelligence agencies were aware of plans to attack the Nord Stream pipelines three months before thwy were bombed.
content: U.S. intelligence agencies learned from a European ally that the Ukrainian military had planned an attack on the Nord Stream pipelines, three months before saboteurs bombed the underwater network, The Washington Post reported on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Trump Praises the PGA and LIV Golf Merger
description: The LIV series has been a boon for the Trump family, which lost major tournaments after the Jan. 6, 2021, assault on the capitol.
content: The Trump family, which has been the host of LIV tournaments in the United States and a big booster of the series’ efforts to break away from the PGA Tour, expects to continue to see tournaments played at its golf courses once the merger is complete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Family Seeks Arrest in Killing of Woman Shot Through Neighbor’s Door
description: Ajike Owens, a mother of four, had gone to a residence in Ocala, Fla., to confront a neighbor after a dispute involving her children. The neighbor has not been identified.
content: A woman in Ocala, Fla., who confronted a neighbor who had thrown an object at her children, was shot and killed “through the door” of the residence, the local sheriff said, in a case that is complicated by the state’s “stand your ground” law after days without a decision on possible charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Grunwald
title: The Climate Solution That’s Horrible for the Climate
description: Corn ethanol and soy biodiesel accelerate food inflation and global hunger, but they’re also a disaster for the climate and the environment.
content: As America rushes to generate more renewable electricity, it has become fashionable to fret that solar and wind farms use too much land. But America is also racing to produce more renewable fuels, and they use much, much more land to displace much, much less fossil fuel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ronnie Cummins, Scourge of Genetically Modified Food, Dies at 76
description: A lifelong protester, he became a leading promoter of organic food and a forceful critic of a food industry that genetically engineers what it produces and sells.
content: Ronnie Cummins, a ponytailed activist who became one of the country’s leading advocates for organic food and a leading critic of genetically modified food, died on April 26 in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, where he lived and worked part-time. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: There Is One Group the Roberts Court Really Doesn’t Like
description: It is difficult to overstate the court’s hostility to organized labor and the rights of American workers.
content: It is difficult to overstate the hostility of the Roberts court to organized labor and the rights of American workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Merck Sues Over Law Empowering Medicare to Negotiate With Drugmakers
description: The company is heavily reliant on a cancer drug that could be targeted by a program intended to lower drug prices.
content: The pharmaceutical company Merck sued the government on Tuesday over a federal law that empowers Medicare for the first time to negotiate prices directly with drugmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: It’s Called the Grand Canyon, Not the Eternal Canyon
description: A rafting trip yields insights about a national treasure that seems permanent but is always being changed, lately by humans.
content: You don’t need me to tell you that the Grand Canyon is magnificent. Otherworldly. Sublime. But, having rafted through 90 miles of the canyon with a group of scientists and grad students, I can tell you that it’s quite a bit more fragile, and less permanent, than you might think.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein, Ephrat Livni and Emily Flitter
title: Coinbase Accused of Breaking Market Rules as Crypto Crackdown Widens
description: The S.E.C. said the cryptocurrency platform allowed users to trade unregistered securities, a day after it accused the crypto platform Binance of mishandling funds.
content: In an intensifying effort to end what the authorities see as the era of lawlessness in the cryptocurrency market, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday sued Coinbase, the largest crypto trading platform in the United States, claiming that the company broke the law by not registering as a broker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Book I Wish Every Policymaker Would Read
description: In “Recoding America,” Jennifer Pahlka offers a deeper theory for why the U.S. government struggles to provide services to its people.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, and exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Can HBO’s ‘The Idol’ Bring Back ’80s Sleaze?
description: Over-the-top locations and characters bathed in red light recall an all but dead genre that was once a staple of late-night cable: the erotic thriller.
content: A slick executive drives a cherry red convertible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Tension Overshadows the Tennis Between Sabalenka and Svitolina
description: Players from Ukraine do not shake hands with players from Russia and Belarus. Aryna Sabalenka waited at the net anyway.
content: In hindsight, this French Open was probably destined to come down to a moment like the one that unfolded Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: An Endgame for Ukraine
description: Membership in the E.U. A security pact with America. And a restoration of borders, minus Crimea.
content: It may be that Ukraine’s long-awaited counteroffensive, which could be in its early stages, will be as fruitless as Russia’s winter offensive. Defenders typically have advantages over attackers in trench warfare, and the Russian Army has had months to dig in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich
title: A Reporter Investigated Sexual Misconduct. Then the Attacks Began.
description: After publishing an exposé, journalists in New Hampshire faced broken windows, vulgar graffiti and a legal brawl, with important First Amendment implications.
content: One drizzly Saturday in May last year, a slender man in a blue raincoat approached a house in the Boston suburb of Melrose. It was just before 6 a.m., and no one was around. The man took out a can of red spray paint and scrawled “JUST THE BEGINNING!” on the side of the white house. Then he hurled a brick through a large window and sprinted away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Shteamer
title: Hardcore Punk Is Looking (and Sounding) Different Now
description: People of color, women and queer musicians are remaking hardcore’s longstanding image of white, male aggression — and producing some of its most interesting music.
content: One afternoon in April, in between sets at a daylong hardcore punk fest, three fans — Shani Nanje, 23; Dominique Wooten, 25; and Elizabeth Zaldivar, 31, all in town from Atlanta — stood in the backyard of the roomy, bare-bones Bushwick venue the Brooklyn Monarch, breaking down how they’ve seen their musical community change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: French March in New Pension Protests, but Are They a Final Stand?
description: After months of widespread protests failed to budge the government, opponents acknowledge that the chances of turning the tide now are slim.
content: Street demonstrations and transport strikes disrupted France again on Tuesday as another day of protests against a widely unpopular pension overhaul took place, in what appeared to be a last-ditch effort to pressure the authorities into scrapping the changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Shawn Hubler
title: Florida Confirms Arranging Migrant Flights to California
description: A spokeswoman for the Florida Division of Emergency Management said that the migrants’ relocation to Sacramento had been “voluntary.”
content: After days of silence, officials in Florida confirmed on Tuesday that the administration of Gov. Ron DeSantis had orchestrated two recent charter flights that carried groups of migrants from New Mexico to Sacramento.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Miriam Silverman Is ‘Unafraid of Embracing the Darkness’
description: In “The Sign in Sidney Brustein’s Window,” the Tony Award nominee inhabits her character, a racist Upper Manhattan snob, in all her flaws.
content: The actress Miriam Silverman came out of the womb to an audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Spotify to Lay Off 200 Employees in Podcast Strategy Shift
description: Spotify said it was cutting 2 percent of its work force and absorbing two popular podcast studios, Gimlet Media and Parcast, into Spotify Studios.
content: Spotify, the audio streaming platform, said on Monday that it planned to lay off about 200 people, including workers at the popular podcast studios Gimlet Media and Parcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Republicans Are No Longer Calling This Election Program a ‘Godsend’
description: Some Republican states are rejecting what was, until a few months ago, widely agreed to be the single best program for keeping voter rolls accurate and up-to-date.
content: To hear many Republicans tell it, American elections are awash in incompetence and fraud: shady precinct workers, dead people voting, unverifiable mail-in ballots and so on — and that was even before the Jan. 6 insurrection. Virtually all of the stories are exaggerated, misleading or simply false. And genuine voter fraud is extraordinarily rare. Still, Republican officials have for a long time rightly insisted on the importance of election integrity. So why are so many of them rejecting what was, until a few months ago, widely agreed to be the single best program for shoring up that integrity?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Evelina Riabenko
title: As Water From Destroyed Dam Rises, Ukrainians Face a Fresh New Horror
description: Many Ukrainians have learned to live with occupation and shelling. On Tuesday a new menace began lapping at their doors.
content: The early morning explosion that woke Oksana Alfiorova from her sleep seemed normal enough, at least for wartime Kherson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich
title: In Canada’s Wilds, a Chilling Inferno Was Also an Omen
description: In “Fire Weather,” the journalist John Vaillant makes the case that the catastrophic — and inevitable — 2016 Fort McMurray wildfire was a sign of things to come.
content: “Is fire alive?” the journalist and author John Vaillant asks early in his new book, “Fire Weather.” I rolled my eyes, even as Vaillant ticks off a dozen lifelike characteristics — it grows, it breathes, it travels in search of nourishment — because the answer seemed so obvious: No. Of course not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Suffix for an Extravaganza
description: Daniel Jaret achieves something wonderful.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Arctic Summer Could Be Practically Sea-Ice-Free by the 2030s
description: In a new study, scientists found that the climate milestone could come about a decade sooner than anticipated, even if planet-warming emissions are gradually reduced.
content: The first summer on record that melts practically all of the Arctic’s floating sea ice could occur as early as the 2030s, according to a new scientific study — about a decade sooner than researchers previously predicted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Geffen and Gustavo: Mixed Boons for the New York Philharmonic
description: The orchestra’s renovated hall and Gustavo Dudamel, its next leader, have kept ticket sales robust, but cool acoustics curb the music’s impact.
content: David Geffen Hall, the New York Philharmonic’s gut-renovated home at Lincoln Center, isn’t perfect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: For Christie, Winning Would Be Great. Beating Trump Would Be a Close Second.
description: The former New Jersey governor’s presidential bid is a long shot. But if he takes out Donald J. Trump along the way, Chris Christie may consider it a victory.
content: Chris Christie is embarking on a mission that even some of his fiercest allies must squint to see ending in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: All Aboard the Most Extravagant Fashion Cruise
description: Chanel in Los Angeles, Dior in Mexico, Gucci in Seoul. Clothes are just a tiny part of the content.
content: In 1964, John Cheever published a short story called “The Swimmer” in which a seemingly happy suburbanite endeavors to swim his way home across New York’s Westchester County, by going from one backyard pool to the next in an odyssey that reveals the truth of his world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Plans to Build in Berkeley Put Values to the Test
description: A conversation with Daniel Duane, who wrote in The New York Times Magazine recently about plans to develop high-density housing in his hometown.
content: As California’s housing crisis spiraled out of control in the 2010s, with rates of homelessness soaring and even affluent families struggling to buy Bay Area homes, a pro-housing movement was born.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Nathan
title: The Horrors of Immigration and the Pleasures of Food in a Debut Novel
description: In Javier Fuentes’s new book, “Countries of Origin,” an undocumented New York pastry chef must start his life over in Spain.
content: Demetrio, the protagonist of Javier Fuentes’s debut novel, “Countries of Origin,” was 13 and on a trip to Niagara Falls in New York when his uncle revealed why they could not cross into Canada. “Then I understood that we were undocumented,” he recalls, “and that being undocumented made us different, limited.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Turner
title: Celebrate Pride at the Tribeca Festival
description: Here are five L.G.B.T.Q.-themed films worth watching at the annual downtown event, which starts Wednesday.
content: The 2023 Tribeca Festival is coinciding with Pride month, and as L.G.B.T.Q. rights come under renewed attack, the festival includes a handful of films that show the resilience of the community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Can Apple Take the Metaverse Mainstream?
description: The iPhone maker is making a bold bet that it can redefine the niche category of virtual reality with its $3,500 goggles.
content: It’s here (or it will be “early next year”): Apple unveiled its long-awaited entry into virtual reality, or what the tech giant calls “spatial computing,” in the form of the Apple Vision Pro, a $3,500 device that looks like exquisitely designed futuristic ski goggles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Casa Lever, in the Lever House on Park Avenue, Gets a Refresh
description: Southern Charm brings biscuits to the West Village, El Cid Cafe will open in the Hispanic Society and more restaurant news.
content: The eye-catching collection of Andy Warhol portraits are gone. The walls of Casa Lever, the elegant Milanese-style Italian restaurant that just reopened after months of renovation in the landmark Lever House on Park Avenue, will now display two colorful Damien Hirst paintings, “Summer of Love” and “Love and Hate.” And the menu offers some new items, including lunchtime surprises like a lobster roll and a dry-aged short rib and brisket cheeseburger, the melt contributed by Taleggio. The menu — with Iacopo Falai, the group’s culinary director, in charge — also includes the addition of hamachi crudo, a crab pancake, paccheri with lobster, pan-seared turbot with artichokes, roast veal, and roasted baby carrots with avocado. In the atrium, the newly redone outdoor seating area and bar has sculptures by Ellsworth Kelly provided by the artist’s foundation in honor of his 100th birthday. Originally designed by Mark Newsom in 2002, the restaurant became Casa Lever when it was taken over by Sant Ambroeus Hospitality Group in 2009. An intimate private wine room has also been added.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Making Manufacturing Great Again
description: Industrial investment has suddenly gone parabolic.
content: Back when Donald Trump began his political rise, it was common for mainstream pundits to attribute his support to “economic anxiety,” to suggest that MAGA was an understandable, maybe even reasonable response to deindustrialization and the loss of jobs in the American heartland. You don’t hear that very much anymore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: 5 Things to Know About Chris Christie
description: Mr. Christie, a onetime star presidential recruit who finished in sixth place in New Hampshire in 2016, has become a fierce Trump critic.
content: Former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who announced a second campaign for president on Tuesday after a disappointing run in 2016, has had a roller coaster of a political career in more ways than one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Winners Get Their Due. But Losers Are Wonderfully Human.
description: There’s glory in defeat. Losses, at least, make athletes more relatable to the rest of us.
content: She couldn’t win a single game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian, Annie Karni and Kate Kelly
title: Hard Right Grinds House to a Halt, Rebuking McCarthy for the Debt Deal
description: Members of the ultraconservative Freedom Caucus effectively shut down the House floor for several hours, calling the speaker’s fiscal compromise with President Biden a betrayal.
content: A group of hard-line Republicans hijacked the House floor on Tuesday, grinding legislative business to a halt for several hours in a striking display of ire at Speaker Kevin McCarthy for making a deal with President Biden to suspend the debt limit and banding together with Democrats to muscle it to passage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Roadblocks and Red Tape: New York’s Cannabis Effort at a Crossroads
description: The state solicited entrepreneurs with cannabis convictions to open the first legal dispensaries, but the effort has fallen behind.
content: When New York State began laying the groundwork for its recreational cannabis industry last year, officials cast atoning for the harm done by the war on drugs as a cornerstone of the ambitious plan — and promised to give people who were previously convicted of marijuana offenses the first opportunity to sell it legally.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 6, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 6, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about the only Black participant in the first national spelling bee competition referred incorrectly to Zaila Avant-garde. She was the first Black American to win the Scripps National Spelling Bee, not the first Black student to do so. (Jody-Anne Maxwell of Jamaica won the bee in 1998.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: The Growing 2024 G.O.P. Field, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: Ambition and Audacity From the School of Hard Knocks
description: Yoshiko Chuma and her company’s “Shockwave Delay” at La MaMa layers movement and music with video and spoken text. It’s a lot to take in.
content: With her latest production, “Shockwave Delay,” the artist Yoshiko Chuma promises that no two performances will be exactly alike. That’s always true of any live performance, but even more so when it comes to the highly collaborative and volatile happenings that Chuma directs for her multidisciplinary company, the School of Hard Knocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Apollo Theater Names New President
description: Michelle Ebanks, who most recently served as the president of Essence Communications, will assume the role in July.
content: Michelle Ebanks, who most recently served as the president of Essence Communications, the global media and communications company dedicated to Black women, will be the next president and chief executive of the Apollo Theater in Harlem, the organization announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Keenan and Rick Rojas
title: Atlanta City Council Approves ‘Cop City’ Funding Despite Protests
description: The vote to approve $31 million for the construction of a sprawling police and fire training complex came after nearly two years of protests.
content: The Atlanta City Council voted overwhelmingly early Tuesday to approve $31 million in funding for the construction of a sprawling $90 million police and fire training complex, backing a project that has provoked nearly two years of sustained protests and further inflamed tensions over law enforcement in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaroslaw Kuisz and Karolina Wigura
title: Poland Isn’t the Friend the West Thinks It Is
description: Illiberalism in the country is alive and well.
content: The war in Ukraine has thrown up many paradoxes. One of the most peculiar is that Vladimir Putin’s invasion made autocratic politicians in neighboring countries look, all of a sudden, like the good guys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul McAdory
title: Why Are the Language Police Obsessed With Vice Presidents?
description: They make countless public appearances that will be mostly ignored — unless there’s something to poke fun at.
content: It’s now a staple of conservative media: Vice President Kamala Harris speaks in batty, confused loops. Her words float from mouth to sky, where they mass into fluffy shapes that hazily resemble meaning. Choice excerpts from her speeches circulate, like this one, delivered on April 25 at Howard University: “I think it’s very important, as you have heard from so many incredible leaders, for us, at every moment in time, and certainly this one, to see the moment in time in which we exist and are present, and to be able to contextualize it, to understand where we exist in the history and in the moment, as it relates not only to the past but the future.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alla Katsnelson
title: Gene Therapy May Offer Birth Control for Cats
description: A small study uses genetic engineering with the goal of curbing vast stray feline populations.
content: For all the cats who share our homes as companion animals, there is a vast shadow world of strays — a sprawling and fast-breeding crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: What Tour Leaders and Players are Saying About the Merger
description: Players and officials are split on the a blockbuster agreement.
content: PGA Tour officials and LIV leaders hailed the announcement on Tuesday that their competing golf series would be joining forces, but players were split on the news. Here’s what they were saying:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Glanz, Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Internal Blast Probably Breached Ukraine Dam, Experts Say (Cautiously)
description: With Russia and Ukraine blaming each other for the collapse of the Kakhovka dam, experts say that an external attack or even structural failure might explain the disaster, but that it is not likely.
content: A deliberate explosion inside the Kakhovka dam, on the front line of the war in Ukraine, most likely caused its collapse on Tuesday, according to engineering and munitions experts, who said that structural failure or an attack from outside the dam were possible but less plausible explanations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: Birds With a Taste for Flesh Threaten Whale Calves
description: In Argentina, kelp gulls are attacking the backs of southern right whales, imperiling the recovery of an endangered species.
content: Thousands of colossal southern right whales travel to the calm waters of Península Valdés off the coast of Argentina each year to breed and give birth. The cetaceans, which can reach 56 feet in length, are a sight to behold, especially with their calves in tow. But if you venture out to see them, you may sometimes find your stomach turning for a reason that has nothing to do with sea sickness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Are Your Pride Songs?
description: We’re asking readers about the songs that first gave them the courage to come out or that still inspire them to live their truth.
content: June is L.G.B.T.Q.+ Pride month — and what’s a Pride celebration without the music?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: World Bank Projects Weak Global Growth Amid Rising Interest Rates
description: A new report projects that economic growth will slow this year and remain weak in 2024.
content: The World Bank said on Tuesday that the global economy remained in a “precarious state” and warned of sluggish growth this year and next as rising interest rates slow consumer spending and business investment, and threaten the stability of the financial system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: In ‘Days of Wine and Roses,’ Two Souls Lost in an Ocean of Booze
description: In Craig Lucas and Adam Guettel’s jazzy new musical, Kelli O’Hara and Brian d’Arcy James are a glamorous couple succumbing to alcoholism.
content: If not for the unbridled drinking, it might easily have been a screwball comedy. Just look at them: Kirsten, blondly beautiful with a tolerant smile and a quick riposte; Joe, curly-haired cute but too arrogant to grasp that he’ll have to up his game to win this woman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
title: Mark Meadows Testified to Grand Jury in Special Counsel Investigation of Trump
description: Mr. Meadows, the final White House chief of staff under Donald Trump, is seen as a potentially key witness in the documents and Jan. 6 inquiries.
content: Mark Meadows, the final White House chief of staff under President Donald J. Trump and a potentially key figure in inquiries related to Mr. Trump, has testified before a federal grand jury hearing evidence in the investigations being led by the special counsel’s office, according to two people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Mooj Zadie, Will Reid, Rikki Novetsky, Clare Toeniskoetter, Sydney Harper, Marc Georges, Liz O. Baylen, Diane Wong, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Fight Over Phonics
description: Why American schools are changing how reading is taught.
content: Over the past three decades, Lucy Calkins helped create a set of strategies for teaching children how to read, known as balanced literacy. It was widely adopted in the United States, including in New York, the country’s largest public school system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: Seven Underappreciated Birding Spots in New York
description: Sure, you know about Central Park and Flushing Meadows. But here are a few more birding locations worth checking out.
content: Birding in New York City is easier than you might think. “The best place to bird in New York is exactly where you are right at that moment,” said Martha Harbison, a writer and vice president of the Feminist Bird Club. “I’ve observed 20 species from my own window. And I live in a very ungreen area of Brooklyn.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: A Tony Nominee Shows Off Her Snug Upper West Side Rental
description: Bonnie Milligan, a star of the musical “Kimberly Akimbo,” has been the lucky occupant of a rent-controlled apartment in Manhattan for 15 years.
content: Bonnie Milligan, an actress known for her vocal range and belting voice, shares a snug rental on the Upper West Side with a college friend who is also a performer. Ms. Milligan’s bedroom is sufficiently small that she has to leave to change her mind. The kitchen and living room are pretty much one and the same space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Takeaways From Prince Harry’s First Day of Testimony Against U.K. Tabloids
description: The self-exiled British prince did not mince words as he finally got his day in court.
content: Prince Harry spent nearly five hours on the witness stand on Tuesday airing his longstanding grievances against Britain’s famously unbridled tabloid press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Who is leading Prince Harry’s legal team?
description: The lawyer leading the courtroom arguments, David Sherborne, has taken on Britain’s tabloid press several times.
content: The members of the legal team representing Prince Harry and the other claimants in the case against Mirror Group Newspapers are accustomed to high-profile cases. Most visible among them is the lawyer leading the arguments in the courtroom, David Sherborne — a well-known and respected lawyer who has long attracted celebrity clients and who has taken on Britain’s tabloid press several times before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Pence Seeks to Go Where No Vice President Has Gone Before
description: In running for the Republican nomination against Donald J. Trump, Mike Pence will be the first vice president to directly challenge the president who originally put him on the ticket.
content: He may not make it to the Oval Office. But he will make it into the history books, at least as an asterisk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Founder of Sexual Wellness Company Indicted on Forced Labor Charges
description: Prosecutors say that Nicole Daedone, who founded OneTaste on promises of nurturing women’s sexuality, abused her followers and lived off them.
content: The founder and a top officer of a San Francisco-based commune and sexual wellness company that promoted “orgasmic meditation,” before questions of abuse began to circulate, were indicted Tuesday on charges of forced labor conspiracy by federal prosecutors in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louisa Lim
title: ‘Owlish’ Is a Darkly Fantastical Parable About Totalitarianism
description: In the fictional city of Nevers, a stand-in for Hong Kong, an adulterous university professor is oblivious to the civic decay around him.
content: Dorothy Tse’s “Owlish” is set in the fictional Nevers, a stand-in for Hong Kong, a city of shadows whose slick, “shimmering, mirrored facades” hide layers of sinister underworld. The book is at once a darkly fantastical parable about totalitarianism, a portrait of a place in metamorphosis and a wild romp about Professor Q, a “hack teacher in a debased, cultureless little city” who cheats on his wife, Maria — a perfect, bloodless government official — in an all-consuming affair with a full-size music-box doll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhoda Feng
title: Review: ‘Being Mr. Wickham’ Tracks a Rake’s Progress
description: In this “Pride and Prejudice” spinoff from Original Theatre, Jane Austen’s infamous knave attempts to set the record straight.
content: It is a truth universally acknowledged that the human body is continually renewing itself. Billions of cells are replaced every day; by some accounts, after 100 days, enough cells will have turned over to generate an entirely new person. After 30 years: You do the math.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Justice Dept. Reaches Cleanup Deal With Houston After Civil Rights Inquiry
description: The agreement is part of the Biden administration’s larger environmental justice agenda, which seeks to redress the disproportional impact of pollution on communities of color around the country.
content: The Justice Department has reached an agreement with the City of Houston to improve trash removal and environmental monitoring after an investigation into the widespread dumping of garbage, including human bodies, in predominantly Black and Latino neighborhoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Venture Capital Giant Sequoia Spins Off China and India Units
description: The Silicon Valley firm said the split would simplify its business, amid rising tensions between the United States and China over technology investment and development.
content: Sequoia Capital, one of Silicon Valley’s most prominent venture capital firms, is breaking itself up, spinning out its Chinese unit into an independent company at a time of rising tensions between China and the United States over investment and access to advanced technologies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Over 300 Cases Tied to Convicted N.Y.P.D. Officers Are Tossed Out
description: The Manhattan district attorney’s office sought the dismissals because of due process violations.
content: The Manhattan district attorney’s office on Tuesday sought the dismissal of 316 convictions tied to a group of New York Police Department officers, sergeants and detectives who have been convicted of crimes related to their work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raissa Bretaña
title: A Scrapbook Offers a Material Glimpse of Another World
description: “The Dress Diary” is an intimate record of one wardrobe — and its era.
content: The way we dress is a fundamental expression of identity: Garments function as indicators of aesthetic tastes, cultural values and social status. For Anne Sykes, an Englishwoman who documented her wardrobe nearly 200 years ago, her clothes are her legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson and Jeremy W. Peters
title: Tucker Carlson Posts First Installment of New Show on Twitter
description: The 10-minute video was similar to a stripped-down version of his former Fox program.
content: Tucker Carlson, the sidelined prime-time Fox News host, on Tuesday released the first installment of what he said would be his new show on Twitter, potentially setting up a confrontation with the cable network, where he remains under contract until early 2025.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Suul Brobakke
title: A Couple Returns to the Same Argument. Over and Over Again.
description: Two actors, partners at the time, discuss their own relationship conflicts between takes of a scripted scene.
content: Several years ago, I got out of a relationship in which arguments were increasingly part of our routine as a couple. I remember always feeling confused after our fights: Why did we say the same words over again in different situations? Why did it become so heated? What was actually said? After we broke up, I kept returning to the arguments we had.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Prince Harry Says Tabloid Intrusion Caused His Chelsy Davy Breakup
description: In written testimony, the prince said his and Ms. Davy’s phones were repeatedly hacked while the two were dating.
content: Much of Harry’s case against Mirror Group Newspapers focuses on leaked details about his relationship with his former girlfriend Chelsy Davy, a Zimbabwean entrepreneur whom he dated on-and-off from early 2004 until mid-2010.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Megan Specia
title: Prince Harry, in Dramatic Testimony, Says Journalists Have ‘Blood on Their Hands’
description: In a remarkable court scene, the prince took the stand for five hours to make his case that his phone was hacked by a newspaper group, as a lawyer for the defense grilled him about his claims.
content: Prince Harry finally got his day in court against the British tabloid press that he has long reviled, taking the stand in London on Tuesday to accuse the Mirror Newspaper Group of hacking his cellphone more than a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Astrud Gilberto: 6 Essential Songs
description: The Brazilian singer radiated quiet poise and subtle undercurrents.
content: Astrud Gilberto, who died on Monday at 83, brought the first, alluring taste of Brazilian bossa nova to countless listeners worldwide. Her collaborations — with Stan Getz, Gil Evans, Stanley Turrentine and others — also helped cement the connections of bossa nova and jazz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: What It’s Like to Play Putin in ‘Patriots’
description: Will Keen embodies Russia’s president in a West End production. “It’s been fascinating how the perception of him and the play keep changing,” he said.
content: On a recent evening, the British actor Will Keen was onstage at the Noël Coward Theater in London playing one of the world’s most divisive men: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Megan Specia
title: Testimony Is Another Chapter in What Has Become a Life of Litigation
description: Prince Harry is getting his day in court as he takes on the tabloids that scrutinized his every move for years, even hacking his phone.
content: Follow our updates as Prince Harry testifies in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja, Ahmed Al Omran and Andrew Das
title: Karim Benzema Joins Al-Ittihad, Becoming Latest Saudi Sports Prize
description: The acquisition of Benzema is part of a billion-dollar project to lure global stars to Saudi Arabia’s top league and expand the kingdom’s sports profile.
content: Karim Benzema, one of soccer’s best players and a fixture at the Spanish giant Real Madrid for more than a decade, has agreed to join the Saudi champion Al-Ittihad on a three-year contract that will make him the latest prize acquisition for a kingdom rapidly expanding its ambitions and influence in sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Actors Authorize Potential Strike With Hollywood Writers Still Picketing
description: The vote does not guarantee a walkout. The actors and studios will begin negotiations on Wednesday.
content: The union that represents more than 160,000 film and television actors voted on Monday night to authorize a strike, two days before it is to begin negotiations on a new labor deal with the Hollywood studios. The result from members of the SAG-AFTRA union, with 98 percent authorizing a strike, was expected, and it came during the sixth week of a strike by Hollywood writers and just a day after the Directors Guild of America tentatively agreed to a new contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Dam Destroyed in Ukraine
description: Also, a victory for the Saudi-backed golf tour.
content: The Kakhovka dam and electric plant in southern Ukraine was destroyed yesterday, sending torrents of water through the breach and forcing tens of thousands of people to evacuate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Destroyed Ukrainian Dam Floods War Zone and Forces Residents to Flee
description: Experts suspect an explosion collapsed the dam on the Dnipro River. Kyiv and Moscow blamed each other, and residents downstream were forced to evacuate to escape the cascading waves.
content: A major dam on the Dnipro River in southern Ukraine was destroyed early Tuesday, sending torrents of water cascading through the breach, flooding a war zone downstream, putting tens of thousands of residents at risk and raising the possibility of long-lasting environmental and humanitarian disasters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Man Convicted of Nonviolent Crime Can Own Gun, U.S. Court Rules
description: The decision, which national groups had been closely watching, was a potential setback to gun regulations spurred by a Supreme Court ruling last year that vastly expanded the right to bear arms.
content: A federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that a man who committed a nonviolent crime cannot be legally prevented from owning a firearm — a potential setback to gun regulations spurred by a Supreme Court ruling last year that vastly expanded the right to bear arms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Astrud Gilberto, 83, Dies; Shot to Fame With ‘The Girl From Ipanema’
description: It was the first song she ever recorded. And it played a key role in making the Brazilian sound known as bossa nova a phenomenon in the United States.
content: Astrud Gilberto, whose soft and sexy vocal performance on “The Girl From Ipanema,” the first song she ever recorded, helped make the sway of Brazilian bossa nova a hit sound in the United States in the 1960s, died on Monday. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlowe Starling
title: It Rocks in the Tree Tops, but Is That Bird Making Music?
description: Scientists are finding more evidence that birdsong parallels human-made music.
content: When a bird sings, you may think you’re hearing music. But are the melodies it’s making really music? Or is what we’re hearing merely a string of lilting calls that appeals to the human ear?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Lashbrook
title: They’re Political Adversaries, and They’re in Love
description: In Cecilia Rabess’s novel, “Everything’s Fine,” a woman considers how to stay true to herself after she falls in love with her ideological antithesis and begins working in an industry she doubts.
content: Does love conquer all? Does it now? Did it ever? These are questions Cecilia Rabess asks in her nimble, discerning debut, “Everything’s Fine.” The novel’s protagonist, Jess, is a young, Black recent college graduate in her first year as an analyst at Goldman Sachs when the book sets out. “The entire building smells like money,” Rabess writes, but Jess is not a fish out of water — her entire young adult life has been defined by the affluence of those around her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina LaCour
title: A Breathtaking Novel About Growing Up Muslim in Post-9/11 New York
description: In Aisha Abdel Gawad’s book, “Between Two Moons,” a pair of Muslim sisters navigate life, love and family in a world that is relentlessly suspicious of them.
content: In the opening scene of Aisha Abdel Gawad’s multifaceted and moving debut novel, “Between Two Moons,” a high school senior, Amira, is awakened by her father on the first day of Ramadan to watch a Libyan cafe owner’s sudden arrest. While her twin sister, Lina, tries to sleep through the incident, Amira joins Baba on the fire escape to observe the action: “The approaching dawn spread like a great purple bruise over New York, but the cafe was illuminated by a streetlight as if by an interrogator’s lamp. The men with their dogs were milling in and out, talking into radios, and taking photographs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: These Hotel Restaurants Don’t Only Cater to Tourists
description: Glamour and great menus abound.
content: Ciao, friends! I’m filling in for our usual host, Nikita. This week, I want to take on what might be the most maligned category in New York dining: the hotel restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘The Comeuppance,’ a Bigger, Chillier Big Chill
description: In his haunting new play, Branden Jacobs-Jenkins updates the reunion genre with too much jungle juice and an otherworldly visitor.
content: School reunions, like work and family ones, are fertile ground for dramatists, offering an excuse to gather disparate characters with a catalog of ready-made conflicts. (There’s always someone who got dumped, dissed or disowned x years ago.) Add alcohol or pot to fuel the resurgence of old feelings and loosen the tongue, then let the heavy compression of the timeline, just a weekend or even a night, do the rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: But Would You Wear It?
description: Apple says its new Vision Pro headset will “shift the way we look at technology.” How about how we look?
content: They talked about the optics. They talked about the computer specs. They talked about the “lenticular glass” and the “new spatial computing platform” and the “aluminum alloy” used in the “primary structural element.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: abeyance
description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word abeyance has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 4 in “Chess’s Governing Body Delays Report on Cheating Scandal” by David Segal and Dylan Loeb McClain:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: D-Day’s Historic Beaches Face a New Onslaught: Rising Seas
description: As climate change speeds coastal erosion in France, can memory be preserved if the famous landing sites of the Allied invasion disappear?
content: POINTE DU HOC, France — Even filled with grass and wildflowers, the craters remain so deep and wide that you can still sense the blasts of bombs that carved them 79 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Judge Sides With Families Fighting Florida’s Ban on Gender Care for Minors
description: A federal judge wrote that the plaintiffs suing to block the new law are “likely to prevail on their claim that the prohibition is unconstitutional.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul and Anemona Hartocollis
title: Columbia University Drops Out of U.S. News Rankings for Undergraduate Schools
description: The Ivy League school said it would no longer share data with the college guide, the first major university to do so. Its relationship with U.S. News has been up and down.
content: Columbia University announced on Tuesday that its undergraduate schools would no longer participate in the U.S. News & World Report college rankings, the first major university to refuse to supply information to the influential undergraduate guide for students and parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Another Debt-Limit Fight in the Halls of the Capitol
description: To cover an odd Washington spectacle, a reporter needs a combination of arcane knowledge and pure stamina.
content: I remember first hearing about some obscure thing called the debt ceiling in the mid-1980s. I was a Washington-based reporter for regional newspapers in Florida owned by The New York Times, and two junior House members from Florida on the Budget Committee were threatening to block a debt-limit increase unless the federal deficit was cut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Read Prince Harry’s Written Statement to the Court
description: Prince Harry’s lawyers filed a statement with the High Court in London before he took the stand in his lawsuit against the Mirror newspaper group.
content: Before Prince Harry took the stand to answer questions in his lawsuit against Mirror Group Newspapers on Tuesday, his legal team filed a written statement to the High Court in London that lays out his version of the facts of the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Is it Bad to Wash Your Hair Every Day?
description: The ideal lathering schedule varies from person to person, experts say. Here’s how to tell what may work for you.
content: Q: I’ve heard that washing your hair every day can strip it of its natural oils, making it dry and brittle and causing scalp irritation. Is that true? And what if I exercise regularly?
source.name: The New York Times

title: The College Admissions Process: No Easy Answers
description: Readers respond to a column by David Brooks. Also: Aid Ukraine, regardless; a court ruling on drag shows; corporate welfare.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wilson Wong
title: For Some, the Only Reason to Watch ‘The Idol’ Is for Blackpink’s Jennie
description: Fans of the K-pop group are tuning in to the new HBO series to marvel at the global pop star in her acting debut.
content: Before airing on HBO, the drama “The Idol” dominated headlines and social media for its controversies: At the Cannes Film Festival, where the first two episodes premiered, the series was widely panned for its graphic sexual content; it was rewritten and reshot after Sam Levinson, the creator of the series “Euphoria,” replaced Amy Seimetz as its director; and in March, Rolling Stone published an article detailing a troubled production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Chaon
title: She’s Back From the Dead, but Life’s Just Not the Same
description: In the novel “My Murder,” the victim of a serial killer finds that her second chance at existence comes with profound dilemmas.
content: Katie Williams’s whip-smart, twisty new novel has an arresting premise: Five women, all victims of the same serial killer, are brought back from the dead — or rather, the murdered women are cloned by a shady government agency. These clones are returned to their grieving families and the lives that had been stolen from them, the memories and feelings and personalities of their original selves still intact for the most part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Lange
title: The Home Cook Who Wants to ‘Blow Up the Kitchen’
description: A new book by the British academic Rebecca May Johnson urges a radical rethinking of just what goes on in the kitchen. For starters, don’t call cooking a labor of love.
content: What don’t we talk about when we talk about cooking? When you forward a recipe to a friend, do you mention the spatters of oil, the physicality of wielding a pan, the nagging feeling that you don’t want to cook or the clean satisfaction of tying an apron string?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Lincoln Center, Seeking New Audiences, Plans to Remake Its West Edge
description: The center hopes a major renovation along Amsterdam Avenue will help shed its elitist image and forge closer ties with Black and Latino residents.
content: Lincoln Center welcomes visitors at its main entrance facing Broadway with an elegant plaza, a majestic fountain and an array of travertine concert halls and theaters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Bolsonaro to Face Trial Over Electoral Fraud Claims
description: Brazil’s former president is accused of spreading false information about the nation’s election systems. A conviction would block him from office for eight years.
content: The News
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: Russia warns that the dam’s destruction is a risk to Crimea’s water supply.
description: The destruction of the Kakhovka dam potentially poses problems for a canal supplying water to Crimea that has for years been a point of geopolitical tension between Kyiv and Moscow, Russian officials warned on Tuesday.
content: The destruction of the Kakhovka dam potentially poses problems for a canal supplying water to Crimea that has for years been a point of geopolitical tension between Kyiv and Moscow, Russian officials warned on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Signs of a counteroffensive in Ukraine.
content: Ukrainian forces have stepped up artillery strikes and ground assaults at several points along the front line. The military action, which began on Sunday, may signal that Kyiv’s long-awaited counteroffensive against Russia has begun, U.S. officials said. The Russian authorities reported yesterday that major Ukrainian attacks had started at five different locations in the eastern region of Donetsk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Why I Can’t Bet Against Apple’s Mixed-Reality Prowess
description: There are plenty of reasons the Vision Pro could flop. But we shouldn’t forget that Apple has a knack for entering a product category at just the right time.
content: I’ll confess that when Apple introduced its mixed-reality Vision Pro headsets on Monday, one of my first thoughts was: Man, that thing looks weird.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Religious School That’s Also a Public School
description: Oklahoma’s decision to allow the Catholic church to operate a public school continues a winning streak for religious conservatives.
content: Religious conservatives often lament they have been on the losing end of recent social trends, and they’re not entirely wrong about that. Same-sex marriage has become legal nationwide. Church attendance is down. About 30 percent of Americans identify as having no religion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Crain
title: Murder, Espionage and a Thick Slice of Soviet Life
description: Refuseniks in 1970s Moscow try to untangle an ax murder in Paul Goldberg’s new novel, “The Dissident.”
content: The sociological description of 1970s Soviet activist life that Paul Goldberg layers onto his new novel, “The Dissident,” is as thick, gleaming and rich as a slab of fatback on rye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen and Justin Porter
title: A Critical Dam Is Destroyed on Ukraine’s Front Line
description: Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The Kakhovka dam and electric plant on the front line in southern Ukraine was destroyed today, sending torrents of water through the breach and forcing tens of thousands of people to evacuate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Anna Shay, Star of Netflix’s ‘Bling Empire,’ Dies at 62
description: A Los Angeles socialite and heiress to a defense contractor, she lived most of her life in private before joining a reality show.
content: Anna Shay, an heiress and Los Angeles socialite who became a breakout star of the Netflix reality show “Bling Empire,” has died. She was 62.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Chua
title: Elliot Page, From Shame to Self-Acceptance, in Hollywood’s Glare
description: In the “brutally honest” memoir “Pageboy,” the actor recounts the fears and obstacles to gender transition, and the hard-won happiness that’s followed.
content: There’s a scene in the third season of Netflix’s hugely popular “The Umbrella Academy” where Elliot Page’s character, sporting a new, short haircut, walks up to the other members of the titular superhero team to suggest a plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Cuba Gooding Jr. Settles Federal Lawsuit That Accused Him of Rape
description: He pleaded guilty last year to a single charge stemming from an allegation of unwanted kissing. The civil trial that was to begin Tuesday included the most serious accusation he faced.
content: On a summer night in 2013, a woman identified in court papers only as Jane Doe was said to have gone for drinks to a SoHo hotel with the actor Cuba Gooding Jr. There, according to a federal lawsuit, he raped her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Hotelier Writes Off San Francisco, Citing ‘Major Challenges’
description: Park Hotels & Resorts said it stopped making payments on a $725 million loan tied to two prominent hotels in a city hit hard by pandemic-related changes.
content: Park Hotels & Resorts, the operator of two of the most prominent hotels in San Francisco, is handing in the keys on the properties — and, in essence, giving up on a city that has fallen on hard times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Ben Protess
title: Grand Jury in Florida Hints at Unknown Complexities in Trump Documents Inquiry
description: Prosecutors have started calling witnesses to a federal grand jury in Miami after months in which activity in the investigation was centered on a separate grand jury in Washington.
content: The latest twist in the inquiry into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of classified documents is the surprise revelation that a previously unknown federal grand jury in Florida has recently started hearing testimony in the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: John Mellencamp Just Might Punch You
description: The irascible rocker, now 71, reflects on how America plays into his music, his relationship to his biggest hits and his latest album, “Orpheus Descending.”
content: “Country artists are writing songs about me now,” John Mellencamp said with something close to bewilderment. “Are you kidding me? You can’t find anything better to write about?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Grace Ashford
title: George Santos Loses Ruling on Anonymity of His Bail Guarantors
description: Mr. Santos, who has vowed to go to jail to keep the identities of his supporters sealed, has been given time to appeal the decision.
content: A federal magistrate judge on Long Island on Tuesday ruled against Representative George Santos’s request to keep private the identities of people who guaranteed his $500,000 bail bond last month, but delayed their release to allow the New York congressman time to appeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Trump Asks Judge to Stop Carroll’s Second Defamation Suit
description: Former President Donald J. Trump told a judge that he could not have defamed E. Jean Carroll by denying her rape accusation because a jury had found him liable only for sexually abusing her.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump told a judge Monday night that he could not have defamed E. Jean Carroll by denying her decades-old rape accusation because a jury had found him liable only for sexually abusing her.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read Prince Harry’s written statement.
description: Statement by Prince Harry in his lawsuit against Mirror Group Newspapers.
content: Statement by Prince Harry in his lawsuit against Mirror Group Newspapers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Kiehart
title: Canvas of Clay
description: The iconic courts at Roland Garros can tell the tale of a match if you look closely enough.
content: The iconic courts at Roland Garros can tell the tale of a match if you look closely enough.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the document
description: Wordle Golf Rules Card
content: Wordle Golf Rules Card
source.name: The New York Times

title: New Jersey Primary Election Results
description: See full results from the New Jersey primary elections.
content: See full results from the New Jersey primary elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby, Lazaro Gamio, Marco Hernandez and Haley Willis
title: Mapping the Flooding From the Dam Breach in Southern Ukraine
description: Maps show where villages were inundated by floodwaters downstream a destroyed dam in southern Ukraine.
content: Maps show where villages were inundated by floodwaters downstream a destroyed dam in southern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: The Grand Canyon, a Cathedral to Time, Is Losing Its River
description: The Colorado River, which carved the Grand Canyon over millions of years, is now in crisis from climate change and overuse.
content: The Colorado River, which carved the Grand Canyon over millions of years, is now in crisis from climate change and overuse.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At Home With Bonnie Milligan
description: The actress, a Tony nominee for her role in “Kimberly Akimbo,” has been the lucky occupant of a rent-controlled apartment in Manhattan for 15 years.
content: The actress, a Tony nominee for her role in “Kimberly Akimbo,” has been the lucky occupant of a rent-controlled apartment in Manhattan for 15 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Critical Dam in Southern Ukraine Destroyed
description: Video verified by The New York Times shows a significant volume of water flowing freely through a destroyed dam and power plant in Nova Kakhovka, Ukraine, posing a threat to communities and infrastructure along the waterway.
content: Video verified by The New York Times shows a significant volume of water flowing freely through a destroyed dam and power plant in Nova Kakhovka, Ukraine, posing a threat to communities and infrastructure along the waterway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Destruction of Dam Causes Flooding in Southern Ukraine
description: Videos verified by The New York Times show downstream flooding after the destruction of the Kakhovka dam and hydroelectric plant on the Dnipro River.
content: Videos verified by The New York Times show downstream flooding after the destruction of the Kakhovka dam and hydroelectric plant on the Dnipro River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Suul Brobakke
title: Study of a Fight
description: Couples often rehash old disputes. Here, two actors, partners at the time, discuss some of their own relationship conflicts through a scripted scene.
content: Couples often rehash old disputes. Here, two actors, partners at the time, discuss some of their own relationship conflicts through a scripted scene.
